greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array: If A001222(n) < k, then A(n,k) = n, otherwise A(n,k) = product of k largest prime factors of n (taken with multiplicity), read by descending antidiagonals.
comment: Square array A(n,k) [where n is row and k is column] is read by descending antidiagonals: A(1,1), A(1,2), A(2,1), A(1,3), A(2,2), A(3,1), etc
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10440; the first 144 antidiagonals of array
example: The top left 5x18 corner of the array:
For A(18,1) we take just the largest prime factor of 18 = 2*3*3, thus A(18,1) = 3.
For A(18,2) we take the product of two largest prime factors of 18 (duplicates not discarded), thus A(18,2) = 3*3 = 9.
For A(18,3) we take the product of three largest prime factors of 18, thus A(18,2) = 3*3*2 = 18.
mathematica: With[{nn = 14}, Function[s, Table[s[[#, k]] &[n - k + 1], {n, nn}, {k, n, 1, -1}]]@ MapIndexed[PadRight[#1, nn, First@ #2] &, Table[FoldList[Times, Reverse@ Flatten[FactorInteger[n] /. {p_, e_} /; e > 0 :> ConstantArray[p, e]]], {n, nn}]]] // Flatten (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Apr 28 2017 *)
program: (define (A285730bi row col) (let loop ((n row) (k col) (m 1)) (if (zero? k) m (loop (/ n (A006530 n)) (- k 1) (* m (A006530 n))))))
;; Alternatively, implemented with the given recurrence formula:
(define (A285730bi row col) (if (= 1 col) (A006530 row) (* (A006530 row) (A285730bi (A052126 row) (- col 1)))))
def a006530(n): return 1 if n==1 else max(primefactors(n))
def A(n, k): return a006530(n) if k==1 else a006530(n)*A(n/a006530(n), k - 1)
for n in range(1, 21): print [A(k, n - k + 1) for k in range(1, n + 1)] # _Indranil Ghosh_, Apr 28 2017
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Apr 28 2017
